awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Quantifying past water table depth and hydroclimate with dissolved noble gas isotopes in groundwater
awd_abstract_narration:
Water resources are a critical issue for agriculture in the arid parts of the US, and it is likely that water availability will be affected by future climate change, yet it remains difficult to predict the magnitude of future rainfall changes. The proposed research will develop a new and precise method for quantifying past changes in water table depth, using measurements of dissolved noble gas isotopes in ancient groundwater.  This knowledge of past water table fluctuations will help illuminate the regional rainfall response to climate variations, and strengthen predictions by providing rigorous tests of rainfall models. 

The method is based on the demonstrated fact that heavy gases settle to the bottom of the stagnant column of air in the soil above the water table depth.  The deeper the water table, the more extreme the enrichment of heavy isotopes, and these heavy isotopes become dissolved in the water thus preserving information about the water table depth in aquifers containing ancient groundwater.  This groundwater is already routinely sampled to learn about past temperature from the abundance of the noble gases; the proposed research will add water table depth to the information that can be extracted from the samples.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this collaborative project was to develop a novel physics-based proxy for quantitative reconstructions of past hydroclimates, using high-precision measurements of dissolved noble gas isotopes in groundwater. The basic idea is that in the unsaturated zone, above the groundwater table, the heavier noble gas isotopes are more enriched the deeper down the groundwater table is located. These gases then dissolve in the water at the water table and are carried deeper into the aquifer by groundwater flow. This water can then be sampled at a well, the time the water spent underground determined by various dating methods (such as radiocarbon), and the water table depth at the time of recharge be determined using this new technique. In addition, bulk noble gas concentrations yield, due to the temperature dependency of their solubility in water, a ground temperature at the time of recharge. A set of samples from various locations (and ages) in the aquifer can then be used to reconstruct a record of paleoclimate parameters such as mean annual temperature and a measure of the wetness of climate for the past 30,000 years or so.

This approach requires ultra-precise isotope ratio measurements, only available since a few years. This project established the procedures (mostly at UC San Diego) and successfully applied the method to aquifers in California and Arizona.

In the Tucson Basin (the field site that I was primarily involved in), noble gas paleotemperatures for the glacial groundwater were lower than those of Holocene origin by about 6 degrees C consistent with other findings in the south-western United States. Water table depth during most of the Holocene was about 20m with a brief drop to 40m in the late Holocene (~2000 years ago) indicating a much drier period. The oldest sample (~30,000 years) shows a considerably shallower water table depth of about 6m which means that this period was much wetter than today.

As the first quantitative method for determining past water table depths, this work will have an impact on water resources research, paleoclimate, atmospheric dynamics (that control the latitude of rain belts, for example), and understanding the mechanism of abrupt climate change as widely recorded in cave deposits (speleothems) at low latitudes and ice cores at both high-altitude low-latitude sites and polar sites.
